attributes.title: Pre-Analysis Plan: Increasing Tax Compliance in Malawian Markets

q1.value: Pre-Analysis Plan: Increasing Tax Compliance in Malawian Markets

q5.value: We thank participants of the Midwestern Working Group on African Political Economy (MGAPE), and of the Contemporary African Political Economy Research Seminar (CAPERS) for valuable feedback on the research design.

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: In Malawi, as in many sub-Saharan African countries, fees from open-air markets form one of the largest sources of ``own'' revenue for local governments. However, current tax compliance levels are low, limiting the ability of local governments to fund service provision. Potential taxpayers, in turn, are reluctant to pay taxes until they see a return on investment of their tax payments in the form of government-provided public services. In scoping interviews conducted with district government officials and market vendors in 2015-2016, the vicious cycle of low tax compliance and low service provision was consistently named as the number one barrier to local government accountability and sustainability in Malawi. Understanding how to kick-start the system to encourage citizens to invest in government and government to invest in public services has the potential for far-reaching effects on governance, accountability, and development. Our experiment tests the effectiveness of two different approaches to improving tax compliance: ``bottom-up'' interventions that focus on increasing quasi-voluntary tax compliance, and ``top-down'' interventions that focus on improving the government's capacity to enforce tax collection and tax collectors' efforts in collecting daily fees, in addition to reducing money lost through corruption by making the transfer of money from the markets to districts more efficient and transparent.

q16.value: We predict that each treatment arm will 1) Increase the percentage of vendors who pay their fees and 2) Increase the revenue per market received by the local government(s). We also predict that the largest effects will be in the group of markets that received both treatment arms. The PAP specifies additional mechanism-related hypotheses.

q17.value: These will be tested using multiple data sources. The key sources for the main hypotheses are 1) a survey of market vendors, in which we collect self-reported tax payments and 2) government revenues collected from each market in each month. We will test whether the treatments

q29.value: No, but PIs did receive remuneration from NORC, who contracted with USAID for the impact evaluation.

attributes.title: Public Response to China’s Economic Inducements: Evidence from the Philippines

q1.value: Public Response to China’s Economic Inducements: Evidence from the Philippines

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: Economic statecraft – the use of economic tools to pursue political goals – has been an important part of China’s foreign policy. However, both large-N analyses and case studies have produced conflicting conclusions on whether economic statecraft is effective. China has often used economic inducements in an effort to influence the policies of target countries, but this has had varying degrees of success. What characteristics of economic statecraft strategies allow or impede political effectiveness? Specifically, what kind of effects do economic inducements have on public opinion in the target country?

q16.value: (H1a) Inducements that subvert established political processes and institutions worsen public attitudes toward China. (H1b) Inducements that subvert established political processes and institutions reduce public support for cooperative foreign policy toward China. (H2ba) Inducements that adhere to established political processes and institutions improve public attitudes toward China. (H2b) Inducements that adhere to established political processes and institutions increase public support for cooperative foreign policy toward China.

q17.value: The sample of N=900 will be drawn using a Qualtrics online panel. Qualtrics panel providers email respondents with a link to take the survey. Aside from age restrictions (over 18), consent to participate, Filipino citizenship, and a gender quota, no other eligibility based on demographic factors is considered. The survey has a total of 3 treatment populations. T0, the control population, receives a neutral, factual description of China’s investment projects in the Philippines. T1 receives a subversive prime in addition to the control vignette, discussing how China’s inducements undermine established political processes and institutions in the Philippines. T2 receives a stakeholder prime in addition to the control vignette, discussing how China’s inducements adhere to established political processes and institutions in the Philippines.

attributes.title: Income Classifications and Public Support for Foreign Aid

q1.value: Income Classifications and Public Support for Foreign Aid

q5.value: This project is funded by the NSF Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement Grant 1647493.

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: Many countries are routinely categorized by international organizations as “Low Income Countries,” “Least Developed Countries,” and with other labels. In other work, I show that these labels cause these countries to receive significantly more aid than they otherwise would, illustrating the power of international organizations to shape these outcomes. In this project, I investigate one reason why aid agencies may overutilize these simplistic classification systems, even when they have superior expertise more unique to their objectives. I propose that aid agencies use externally-created classification systems to signal their impartiality to their donor publics. In the words of one U.S. Treasury official, “When we can show that most of our aid is benefiting Least Developed Countries (LDCs) or fragile and conflict affected states, this helps our numbers.” Aid agencies can’t credibly communicate to their publics that they use aid to advance development (Milner, 2006). Allocating aid based on a classification system devised by an international organization provides the necessary credibility to communicate to a donor public that aid is being spent impartially. One goal of the project is therefore to investigate whether individuals’ attitudes toward foreign aid are affected by appeals to development classifications. I also use this project to study individuals as donors in their own right, not just principals that aid agencies are accountable to. I investigate whether individuals’ private contributions are swayed by development classifications. This matters for international non-governmental organizations, who often rely on financial and public support in advanced industrial countries to carry out development projects in other parts of the world.

q16.value: Hypothesis 1. Using self-created classifications to show that an aid agency uses its resources to support development will weakly improve approval of the aid agency’s performance. Hypothesis 2. Using externally-created classifications to show that an aid agency uses its resources to support development will significantly improve approval of the aid agency’s performance. Hypothesis 3. Individuals will be more likely to donate to a charity in a country when that country is classified as a developing country, and less likely to donate a charity that is in a country classified as a non-developing country.

q17.value: The hypotheses are tested using an online survey experiment. Individuals are sorted into one of three treatment conditions: (1) control, (2) World Bank classification, and (3) U.S. classification. All groups, including the control group, are introduced to the topic of foreign aid and are asked for their priors about how aid is and should be spent. Next, the treatment groups see a screen containing additional information about how aid in 2016 was spent according to classifications. Group 2 learns that 80% of that aid was for countries that the World Bank classifies as Low or Lower-Middle Income Countries. Group 3 learns that 76% of that aid was classified by the U.S. as development or humanitarian assistance. To test hypothesis 1, I compare groups 1 and 3. To test hypothesis 2, I compare groups 1 and 2. After the foreign aid experiment, I conduct a second experiment to test whether income classifications affect private giving behavior. Individuals are told about an international charity and its work and are subsequently invited to donate to this charity. All individuals hear about a country that the charity does work in (Malawi or Botswana). A treatment group is informed of that country’s income classification by the World Bank; this information is omitted for a control group. The treatments follow a 2x2 factorial design, with a classification and a no classification group for each country, which allows me to test hypothesis 3. For this hypothesis, the outcomes include an individual’s reported willingness to donate to the charity and whether they subsequently click on a link to the charity’s donation webpage.

attributes.title: Positive and negative messages about women in politics and the effects on women’s willingness to participate in politics

q1.value: Positive and negative messages about women in politics and the effects on women’s willingness to participate in politics

q2.value: Roosmarijn De Geus | John McAndrews | Peter Loewen

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: This study seeks to explore the effects of both positive and negative messages about women in politics on women's willingness to participate in politics as well as their sense of representation in politics.

q16.value: We hypothesise that exposure to examples of female leaders increases women's willingness to participate in politics as well as their sense of representation. We further hypothesise that exposure to negative information about women in politics (in this case information about allegations of sexual misconduct against male politicians) will have a negative effect on women's willingness to participate in politics and their sense of representation.

q17.value: For the first hypothesis we will use an experimental set up whereby our sample is randomly exposed to either 2, 1 or 0 examples of female leadership. We will estimate treatment effects using an OLS regression model. For the second hypothesis we will use an experimental set up whereby half of our sample is asked to complete questions about participation and representation prior to reading about allegations of sexual misconduct and the other half of our sample is asked to complete these questions after having read about allegations of sexual misconduct. We will use on OLS regression model to estimate the treatment effect.

registration_responses.q1: Positive and negative messages about women in politics and the effects on women’s willingness to participate in politics

attributes.title: Youth Activists, Police and Election Violence: Evidence from a Field Experiment in Liberia

q1.value: Youth Activists, Police and Election Violence: Evidence from a Field Experiment in Liberia

q2.value: Sabrina Karim | Lindsey Pruett | Alex Dyzenhaus | Grant Buckles

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: In post conflict societies, elections can be a flash point for violencec, often between youth activists and police officers, yet the role of these mid-level political actors is not often included in studies on electoral violence. How can researchers best understand the attitudes and perceptions of actors who are often involved in violent incidents? How can these attitudes change? We use a field experiment and panel survey data around the Liberia's 2017 presidential election to address the perceptions of youth activists and police officers towards democratic elections and electoral violence. The goal of this locally conceived project is first, to better understand how certain political actors view electoral violence and party competition, as well how youth activists and police officers interact with one another. The inter-group dynamics and tension between these actors can impact how elections unfold. The second goal is to analyze the outcomes of a two-part project (a series of workshops and a mentorship program) on a) the likelihood of support for electoral violence as opposed to b) support for and willingness to use formal institutional channels when conveying political grievances. We examine a set of three interconnected mechanisms that could lead youth and police to increase their respect for democratic institutions, and to improve inter-group relations between some of the actors most likely to be involved in election violence. These mechanisms are a) increased inter-group contact, b) higher levels of inter-group trust and c) improved knowledge of formal administrative institutions.

q16.value: H1a: Participation in the program will decrease police and youth's perception of violence as an appropriate means to resolve disagreement and conflict. They will be more likely to view violence as optional, rather than inevitable. H1b: Participation in the program will increase youths' perceptions of democratic institutions as a viable and preferred form of government. H2: Participation in the program will increase contact between police and youth party members. H3: Participation in the program will make youth and police see each other in a more positive way. H4: Participation in the program will make youth and police more likely to report that they will use legal routes for conflict resolution.

q17.value: We will test the hypotheses using difference-in-means and difference-in-difference analyses, as appropriate. We will do analyses on two sub-groups within the sample, and on two different treatments, but we are primarily interested in the overall effect of the project on treated participants. We will run analysis without control variables unless treatment groups are unbalanced.

attributes.title: Explaining Public Support for Militarizing Law Enforcement: Evidence from Conjoint Experiments in Mexico and the United States

q1.value: Explaining Public Support for Militarizing Law Enforcement: Evidence from Conjoint Experiments in Mexico and the United States

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: Across the world, law enforcement has become increasingly militarized. Militarization has taken place in the form of police adopting characteristics of the armed forces—as with SWAT teams in the United States—and in the form of constabularized militaries taking on domestic law enforcement roles, as in many Latin American countries. In such places as Colombia, El Salvador, Guatemala, Honduras, Mexico, and Venezuela, the armed forces conduct semi-permanent law-enforcement tasks across the national territory, including patrolling neighborhoods, staffing checkpoints, conducting arrests, and serving as prison guards. Although a growing body of research points to mixed results (den Heyer 2013; American Civil Liberties Union 2014; Cooper 2015; Singal 2014; Delehanty et al 2017), the militarization of law enforcement has enjoyed widespread public support. According to the Americas Barometer, over 60% of Latin Americans approve of the military intervening in combating crime. However, in this context of uncertainty about militarization’s consequences, the reasons behind this popularity remain poorly understood. This study seeks to answer the following main questions: 1. Do people perceive more militarized law enforcement personnel to be more effective? 2. If so, do certain attributes (e.g., uniform, weapons, gender, skin color) contribute to this perception? 3. Is there a relationship between militarization and perceptions of effectiveness, respect for civil liberties, proclivity to corruption, and willingness to accept militarization of law enforcement in one’s neighborhood? 4. Is militarization of law enforcement associated with a particular government ideology? 5. Does the nature of the perceived threat shape differences in perceptions about militarization?

q16.value: Main Effects Effectiveness H1a: Military uniform will increase perceptions of effectiveness. H1b: Assault rifle will increase perceptions of effectiveness. H1c: Male will increase perceptions of effectiveness. H1d: Light skin will increase perceptions of effectiveness. H2: The difference in perceived effectiveness will be greater when respondents receive information about the type of threat in terms of fighting crime as opposed to providing public safety/law enforcement. Civil liberties H3a: Military uniform will be associated with a higher likelihood of violating civil liberties. H3b: Assault rifle will be associated with a higher likelihood of violating civil liberties. H3c: Male will be associated with a higher likelihood of violating civil liberties. H3d: Dark skin will be associated with a higher likelihood of violating civil liberties. Corruption H4a: Military uniform will be associated with lower corruption. H4b: Assault rifle will be associated with lower corruption. H4c: Female will be associated with lower corruption. H4d: Light skin will be associated with lower corruption. Support for operating in one’s neighborhood H5a: Military uniform will be associated with support for operating in one’s neighborhood in Mexico, but opposition in the US. (Differentiated effect based on perceptions of violence.) H5b: Assault rifle will be associated with support for operating in one’s neighborhood in Mexico, but opposition in the US. (Differentiated effect based on perceptions of violence.) H5c: Female will be associated with support for operating in one’s neighborhood. H5d: Light skin will be associated with support for operating in one’s neighborhood. Ideology H6a: Military uniforms will be associated with right-wing governments. H6b: Assault rifle will be associated with right-wing governments. H6c: Female will be associated with right-wing governments. (No priors for light vs dark skin and ideology). H7: The difference in association with right-wing governments between military and police will be greater when respondents receive information about public safety as opposed to fighting crime. Heterogeneous effects Although we may not have enough statistical power to evaluate main effects by subgroups, we advance the following hypotheses regarding heterogeneous effects given baseline characteristics. More militarized features (e.g., a military uniform, assault rifle) will be perceived as more effective among respondents that are white, favor order over liberty, identify as conservative, identify with right-of-center parties (such as the Republican Party in the US or the PAN in Mexico), distrust the police, trust the armed forces, do not interact with the police frequently, feel insecure in their neighborhoods, and have been victims of crime.

q17.value: We follow an image-based conjoint design and mediation analysis to understand whether people generally prefer more militarized law enforcement personnel, which factors contribute to this perception, and whether support is contingent on the type of security threat implied. Respondents will first be asked to read a short sentence in which we explain that they will be looking at images of two people. Following the statement, respondents will be presented with two similar images (controlling for the pose, size, height, facial expression, background) of security agents. The images will randomly vary in four attributes (uniform, weapon, race, and sex) for a total of 16 different profiles. Following the two images, respondents are asked questions on effectiveness, government affiliation, desirability, corruption, and civil liberties. The images will appear at the beginning of every single question to ease the cognitive burden, rather than having to memorize the agent’s profiles. We also leverage the question wording to conduct a mediation analysis on how perceptions of threat mediate the effect of militarized law enforcement on effectiveness and rule of law by randomizing whether respondents are prompted about personnel “participating in public safety/law enforcement” or “fighting crime.”

q27.value: Researchers, In Mexico, the intervention was be implemented by the UECS Lab at CIDE University

H7: The difference in association with right-wing governments between military and police will be greater when respondents receive information about public safety as opposed to fighting crime. Heterogeneous effects Although we may not have enough statistical power to evaluate main effects by subgroups, we advance the following hypotheses regarding heterogeneous effects given baseline characteristics. More militarized features (e.g., a military uniform, assault rifle) will be perceived as more effective among respondents that are white, favor order over liberty, identify as conservative, identify with right-of-center parties (such as the Republican Party in the US or the PAN in Mexico), distrust the police, trust the armed forces, do not interact with the police frequently, feel insecure in their neighborhoods, and have been victims of crime.
registration_responses.q17: We follow an image-based conjoint design and mediation analysis to understand whether people generally prefer more militarized law enforcement personnel, which factors contribute to this perception, and whether support is contingent on the type of security threat implied. Respondents will first be asked to read a short sentence in which we explain that they will be looking at images of two people. Following the statement, respondents will be presented with two similar images (controlling for the pose, size, height, facial expression, background) of security agents. The images will randomly vary in four attributes (uniform, weapon, race, and sex) for a total of 16 different profiles. Following the two images, respondents are asked questions on effectiveness, government affiliation, desirability, corruption, and civil liberties. The images will appear at the beginning of every single question to ease the cognitive burden, rather than having to memorize the agent’s profiles. We also leverage the question wording to conduct a mediation analysis on how perceptions of threat mediate the effect of militarized law enforcement on effectiveness and rule of law by randomizing whether respondents are prompted about personnel “participating in public safety/law enforcement” or “fighting crime.”
registration_responses.q27: Researchers, In Mexico, the intervention was be implemented by the UECS Lab at CIDE University

attributes.title: Bottom-up accountability and infrastructure delivery: evidence from nurseries and schools' constructions in Brazil

q1.value: Bottom-up accountability and infrastructure delivery: evidence from nurseries and schools' constructions in Brazil

q2.value: Umberto Mignozzetti | Manoel Galdino Pereira Neto | Jessica Voigt Quintino Pereira

q5.value: We acknowledge the 2016 Google Social Impact Challenge for funding the project.

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher analysis of outcome data

q15.value: This project studies how bottom-up accountability influences the infrastructure delivery in developing countries. In Brazil, the Federal Government transfer funds to municipalities to prop the construction of public schools and daycares. However, the absence of pressure over the municipal officials may correlate with delayed delivery of these public infrastructure sites. In this project, we develop a cellphone application that allows citizens to verify if there are delayed constructions in their municipalities and if so, to pressure the mayor's office in order to advance the construction. If municipalities fail to comply with the citizens' requests, we notify the Federal Government funding agency, that may impose penalties to the municipality. We expect that this bottom-up pressure, coupled with the possibility of escalation to the Federal Government, decrease inefficiencies, diminish delays, and also foster the provision of more realistic finishing times for these constructions. Moreover, we expect to find heterogeneous effects for the state capacity of the municipality, based on the contact emails provided by the Federal Government. This project has implications for the design of non-electoral accountability strategies, and citizen's influence on the municipal governments.

q16.value: We test the following hypothesis: H1: Bottom-up pressure decreases the delay in the school constructions; H2: Bottom-up pressure increases the chance that municipalities change their expected finishing times; H3: The effects are stronger in municipalities with institutional emails, as they represent a higher state capacity.

q17.value: From the 2207 municipalities with public constructions funded by the central government, we select 150 to be in the control group. Then we compare a matched sample of treated municipalities with a matched sample of control municipalities.

registration_responses.q1: Bottom-up accountability and infrastructure delivery: evidence from nurseries and schools' constructions in Brazil
registration_responses.q2: Umberto Mignozzetti | Manoel Galdino Pereira Neto | Jessica Voigt Quintino Pereira
registration_responses.q5: We acknowledge the 2016 Google Social Impact Challenge for funding the project.

attributes.title: Pre-Analysis Plan for an Experiment on Confidence in the Police, Fear of Retaliation, and Willingness to Report Drug-Related Crimes: Evidence from Uruguay

q1.value: Pre-Analysis Plan for an Experiment on Confidence in the Police, Fear of Retaliation, and Willingness to Report Drug-Related Crimes: Evidence from Uruguay

q2.value: Juan A. Bogliaccini | Diego Pereira | Juan Ignacio Pereira | James Monogan

q5.value: We thank Maarten Voors, Tara Slough, Jake Bowers, Natalia Garbiras Díaz, and Andrés Moya for the feedback they provided on this design during EGAP's Learning Days workshop in April 2019.

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: The study focuses on willingness to report crimes among citizens of Montevideo, Uruguay. This document outlines a pre-analysis plan for analyzing data from a survey experiment to be administered through Qualtrics. Recruiting will be done through Facebook advertising targeted in Montevideo. This plan has been written prior to any data collection and analysis. The design has been reviewed and approved by the IRB at the University of Georgia and the Ethics Committee at the Universidad Católica del Uruguay. The researchers are not receiving remuneration from any third-party implementing agency. The research is one of the outcomes of a larger study financed by a Grant from the Investigation and Innovation Agency (ANII) and the Ministry of Internal Affairs (Ministerio del Interior) of Uruguay [Grant FSSC-1-2018-1-147750]. When citizens are witnesses to crimes, several factors weigh on their choice of whether to report the crime to police. In this paper, we consider three. First, what is their level of confidence in what the police are able to do? Second, we consider the nature of who is committing the crime--random strangers or established drug gangs? Third, how much fear do the citizens have of retaliation by criminals for snitching? We believe that all of these factors can affect law-abiding citizens in any place. In our study, we plan to estimate the degree to which these various factors are important to people. Increasing citizens’ willingness to report crimes is a major concern for public security. Since most public security interventions rely on identifying crime patterns based on reported crimes, understanding people’s behavioral tendencies is the starting point to nudge them to decide to report crimes. Uruguay has seen a big increase in crimes related to gang activities. This increase is primarily related to small bands of drug sellers who fight for territory and occupy big neighborhoods in Montevideo’s boundaries. Not only are people who live in those neighborhoods affected by these circumstances, but this also affects people living in other neighborhoods where there are no gangs. In these wealthier parts of the city, property crimes with violence have increased since drug gangs have emerged on the outskirts. The gang issue therefore is broadly important.

q16.value: *In a vignette experiment, if respondents are asked whether they would report a crime as a bystander if they are seen by criminals, they will be less likely to report a crime than those who did not receive the treatment. *In a vignette experiment, if respondents are asked whether they would report a crime as a bystander if the criminals are from a local drug gang, they will be less likely to report a crime than those who did not receive the treatment. *Citizens who have higher confidence in the police will be more likely to report crimes.

q17.value: To evaluate how the nature of a crime affects Uruguayans' willingness to report the crime to the police, we present each respondent with a scenario of a hypothetical instance in which he or she witnesses a crime. The respondent will be given one of four possible conditions based on a 2x2 design. One treatment is whether the respondent recognizes the criminals as being from a local drug band or not. The other treatment is whether the respondent was seen by the criminals or not. Thus, each surveyed individual will be randomly assigned to one of the four possible conditions based on all of the pairwise combinations of these two treatments. Importantly, considering these four categories, we will test that control variables are balanced across treatments. In other words, the average value of each covariate should be equal regardless of the assigned vignette. After reading the vignette, the respondent is then asked to rate on a scale of 1 to 7 how likely he or she would be to report this crime to the police. This 1 to 7 rating of willingness to report crime serves as our dependent variable. We will estimate a multilevel linear model, with random effects for 62 neighborhoods, of willingness to report crime. Besides indicators for the two treatments, and their interaction, we also will include a measure of confidence in the police as a predictor to test our third hypothesis. We also will control for having been a victim of a crime, gender, and any imbalanced covariates.

registration_responses.q1: Pre-Analysis Plan for an Experiment on Confidence in the Police, Fear of Retaliation, and Willingness to Report Drug-Related Crimes: Evidence from Uruguay
registration_responses.q2: Juan A. Bogliaccini | Diego Pereira | Juan Ignacio Pereira | James Monogan
registration_responses.q5: We thank Maarten Voors, Tara Slough, Jake Bowers, Natalia Garbiras Díaz, and Andrés Moya for the feedback they provided on this design during EGAP's Learning Days workshop in April 2019.
